articles.headline: College Endowments Opt for Alternative, and Less Lucrative, Route
articles.snippet: The allure of investment options like hedge funds and venture capital remains strong for universities, even though standard stock index funds have outperformed them in the last 10 years.
articles.abstract: The allure of investment options like hedge funds and venture capital remains strong for universities, even though standard stock index funds have outperformed them in the last 10 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s official: Returns for college and university endowments for the 2017 fiscal year are in, and while they averaged a respectable 12.2 percent for the year, over the last decade they have underperformed funds offering a simple 60-40 or 70-30 stock-fixed income allocation.

articles.headline: A Supreme Court Showdown Could Shrink Unions’ Power
articles.snippet: Workers in a small Illinois town are worried that a Supreme Court decision curbing union power would hurt their community.
articles.abstract: Workers in a small Illinois town are worried that a Supreme Court decision curbing union power would hurt their community.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHESTER, Ill. — Randy Clover is something of an anomaly — the president of a union local here that represents Illinois state employees, and a Republican precinct leader who voted for President Trump. But he has no doubt about what will be at stake next week at the Supreme Court: the financial and political clout of one of organized labor’s last strongholds.

articles.headline: Mueller Files New Fraud Charges Against Paul Manafort and Rick Gates
articles.snippet: The charges do not involve President Trump or his campaign, but they compound the legal problems for Mr. Manafort, his former campaign chairman.
articles.abstract: The charges do not involve President Trump or his campaign, but they compound the legal problems for Mr. Manafort, his former campaign chairman.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even as he was managing Donald J. Trump’s campaign for president, Paul Manafort lied to banks to secure millions of dollars in cash loans as part of a decade-long money laundering scheme, according to charges unsealed by the special counsel on Thursday.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: As Gunman Rampaged Through Florida School, Armed Deputy ‘Never Went In’
articles.snippet: Surveillance video showed the only armed sheriff’s deputy at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., doing “nothing” during last week’s deadly shooting.
articles.abstract: Surveillance video showed the only armed sheriff’s deputy at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., doing “nothing” during last week’s deadly shooting.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, Feb. 24, 2018: The Broward County Sheriff’s Office said it was investigating whether other deputies from the department did not go into Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School to engage the gunman.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder and Patricia Mazzei

articles.headline: Beijing Takes Over Anbang, Insurer That Owns Waldorf Astoria
articles.snippet: The troubled Chinese company had spent billions of dollars buying up hotels and other high-profile properties around the world.
articles.abstract: The troubled Chinese company had spent billions of dollars buying up hotels and other high-profile properties around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese government said on Friday that it had seized control of Anbang Insurance Group, the troubled Chinese company that owns the Waldorf Astoria hotel and other marquee properties around the world, and it had charged the company’s former chairman with economic crimes.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Another Shooting, Another Gun Debate. Will the Outcome Be the Same?
articles.snippet: Last week’s school massacre in Florida set the well-worn machinery of America’s gun debate in motion. But angry students injected new passion into a stale fight.
articles.abstract: Last week’s school massacre in Florida set the well-worn machinery of America’s gun debate in motion. But angry students injected new passion into a stale fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Around 2:30 p.m. on Valentine’s Day, President Trump was in the study off the Oval Office when John F. Kelly, his chief of staff, arrived with news of a school shooting in Florida. Mr. Trump shook his head, according to an aide, and muttered, “Again.”
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Iran Finally Let Her See Her Husband. He Was Dead.
articles.snippet: The authorities say Kavous Seyed Emami, a prominent environmentalist, committed suicide in prison. His wife and sons doubt that, and are demanding answers.
articles.abstract: The authorities say Kavous Seyed Emami, a prominent environmentalist, committed suicide in prison. His wife and sons doubt that, and are demanding answers.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — When the call finally came, Maryam Seyed Emami’s heart leapt. Except for one brief phone call, she had heard nothing from her husband, Kavous Seyed Emami, a professor and prominent environmentalist, since he was arrested and accused of spying more than two weeks before. Now, she was being told to come to the offices of the Tehran prosecutor, where she could see her husband at last.

articles.headline: Lowest Ever Black Jobless Rate Is Still Twice That of Whites
articles.snippet: The unemployment rate for black workers hit its lowest point on record recently. But even a strong labor market has limits in spreading opportunity widely.
articles.abstract: The unemployment rate for black workers hit its lowest point on record recently. But even a strong labor market has limits in spreading opportunity widely.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump celebrated the milestone on Twitter and in his State of the Union address. The unemployment rate for black Americans had hit its lowest point on record, a sign that the recovery was at last reaching groups that had been left behind.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: Rick Gates, Trump Campaign Aide, Pleads Guilty in Mueller Inquiry and Will Cooperate
articles.snippet: The plea deal could be a sign that Mr. Gates plans to share incriminating information against Paul Manafort, the former Trump campaign chairman, or other members of the campaign.
articles.abstract: The plea deal could be a sign that Mr. Gates plans to share incriminating information against Paul Manafort, the former Trump campaign chairman, or other members of the campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A former top adviser to Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign has agreed to cooperate with the special counsel inquiry into Russia’s interference in the 2016 election after pleading guilty on Friday to financial fraud and lying to investigators.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Trump Announces Harsh New Sanctions Against North Korea
articles.snippet: The action was a clear signal, near the end of an Olympic Games marked by a rapprochement on the Korean Peninsula, that his pressure campaign would not let up.
articles.abstract: The action was a clear signal, near the end of an Olympic Games marked by a rapprochement on the Korean Peninsula, that his pressure campaign would not let up.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump announced harsh new sanctions on Friday against North Korea, signaling a return to his aggressive attempt to put pressure on the government of Kim Jong-un after an Olympic Games that had brought a brief lull in the tensions on the Korean Peninsula.
